Edward,

I believe that the full sensitivity-analysis capabilities have not=
 yet been incorporated into cantera.  For my flame simulations, I use the "=
brute-force" method.  To do this, you change the rate of each reaction by a=
 specified amount and resolve the problem.  

Here is part of a stagnation =
flame script for a mechanism with 175 reactions (San Diego mechanism):

	f.=
restore('run226_SDmech_20050218_multi.xml','energy')
	f.init()
	f.set(energ=
y =3D 'off')
	f.solve(loglevel,0)
	f.set(energy =3D 'on')
	f.solve(loglevel=
,0)
	f.solve(loglevel,0)
	write.csvwriteshort(prefix+'init_energy',f,gas)
	=
M=3D1.5
	for i in range(0,175):
		f.restore('run226_SDmech_20050218_multi.x=
ml','energy')
		gas.setMultiplier(M,i)
		f.set(energy =3D 'off')
		f.solve(=
loglevel,0)
		f.set(energy =3D 'on')
		f.solve(loglevel,0)
		f.solve(loglev=
el,0)
		write.csvwriteshort(prefix+'M=3D1.5_'+str(i),f,gas)
		gas.setMultip=
lier(1,i)
		print 'finished solution '+str(i)

I implemented 2 solve steps =
for redundancy.  The function "write" is a python script that I wrote for w=
riting the output to file, so this would have to be replaced by your data o=
utput routine.

The output can then be postprocessed to get the sensitivity=
 of any simulation feature to each of the reactions.

I can't help with the=
 time-step jacobian, as I am not quite familiar enough with the "guts" of c=
antera.

Hope this helps,
Jeff

are how deep in the solver this may be.  I would just like some hints.

any=
